citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have the records available at the facility for examination by Animal Plant
Health Inspection Service officials. Each exhibitor shall allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept by
the Act and the regulations in this part; including Acquisition and Disposition records, Program of Vet Care, Environmental
Enhancement Plan and Contingency Plan, in order to ensure the welfare of the animals.
Correct by 11 December, 2023

The 34 adult and 10 juvenile guinea pigs were being housed in a large blue enclosure that measured 68 inches in
diameter. The enclosure provided 3,630 inches of space. The adult guinea pigs required 3,434 inches of space (34 x 101)
and the juveniles require 600 inches of space (10 x 60), so a total of 4,034 inches of space is required for the number of
guinea pigs in the enclosure. The enclosure did not provide sufficient space, as required by the Animal Welfare Act for the
number of guinea pigs housed therein.
Correct by 15 December, 2023

In the large petting zoo area, a chicken wire enclosure was no longer in good repair with sharp points and accessible to
the alpaca, 2 cavies and 3 kangaroos. Sharp points can cause injuries to the animals.
In the sloth enclosure, the humidifier was not functioning and neither was the wall mounted heater, so a temporary heater
was placed in the enclosure. Both the heater and humidifier had exposed electrical cords, and the temporary heater was
on and presented a risk of injury because the heating element was exposed to the animal. Housing facilities shall be
structurally sound, maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
Correct by 20 December, 2023

Upon entering the facility, there was a group of flies just circling. During inspection, the employees removed the full fly
strip from the kitchen area, and described the pest control program including an electric fly catcher that was down for
cleaning, but it does not appear to be effective. A safe and effective program for the control of insects shall be established
and maintained.
Correct by 15 December, 2023

During the inspection, a green winged macaw was observed to be playing with a metal object with jagged edges and
sharp points. As soon as the bird dropped the item, the facility removed the item from the enclosure, identifying it as a
metal bell that had been destroyed. Surfaces, including toys and other enrichment objects that come in contact with birds
must be free of jagged edges or sharp points that could injure the birds.
Corrected during inspection.

Open trash containers were present in both the housing and kitchen areas of the facility, and were accessible to pests
and contributing to the fly issue. Trash containers must be able to contain trash securely to minimize odors and be
inaccessible to animals and pests.
Correct by 15 December, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have the records available at the facility for examination by Animal Plant 
Health Inspection Service officials. Each exhibitor shall allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept by 
the Act and the regulations in this part; including Acquisition and Disposition records, Program of Vet Care, Environmental 
Enhancement Plan and Contingency Plan, in order to ensure the welfare of the animals. 
 
Correct by 11 December, 2023 
3.28(c)(1)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The 34 adult and 10 juvenile guinea pigs were being housed in a large blue enclosure that measured 68 inches in 
diameter. The enclosure provided 3,630 inches of space. The adult guinea pigs required 3,434 inches of space (34 x 101) 
and the juveniles require 600 inches of space (10 x 60), so a total of 4,034 inches of space is required for the number of 
guinea pigs in the enclosure. The enclosure did not provide sufficient space, as required by the Animal Welfare Act for the 
number of guinea pigs housed therein. 
 
Correct by 15 December, 2023 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the large petting zoo area, a chicken wire enclosure was no longer in good repair with sharp points and accessible to 
the alpaca, 2 cavies and 3 kangaroos. Sharp points can cause injuries to the animals.  
In the sloth enclosure, the humidifier was not functioning and neither was the wall mounted heater, so a temporary heater 
was placed in the enclosure. Both the heater and humidifier had exposed electrical cords, and the temporary heater was 
on and presented a risk of injury because the heating element was exposed to the animal. Housing facilities shall be 
structurally sound, maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
 
Correct by 20 December, 2023

3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
Upon entering the facility, there was a group of flies just circling. During inspection, the employees removed the full fly 
strip from the kitchen area, and described the pest control program including an electric fly catcher that was down for 
cleaning, but it does not appear to be effective. A safe and effective program for the control of insects shall be established 
and maintained. 
 
Correct by 15 December, 2023 
3.150(c)(3) 
   
Facilities, general. 
During the inspection, a green winged macaw was observed to be playing with a metal object with jagged edges and 
sharp points. As soon as the bird dropped the item, the facility removed the item from the enclosure, identifying it as a 
metal bell that had been destroyed. Surfaces, including toys and other enrichment objects that come in contact with birds 
must be free of jagged edges or sharp points that could injure the birds. 
 
Corrected during inspection. 
3.150(f) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Open trash containers were present in both the housing and kitchen areas of the facility, and were accessible to pests 
and contributing to the fly issue. Trash containers must be able to contain trash securely to minimize odors and be 
inaccessible to animals and pests. 
 
Correct by 15 December, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
